content: Ask Me About My Weight—But Only When I’m in the Ring As a woman who boxes, cutting my weight comes with a lot of emotional baggage Elena Cresci Blocked Unblock Follow Following Apr 16 Illustration: Claire Merchlinsky I was dehydrated, hungry and grumpy, and trying to get my bath water as hot as possible. Someone told me I could create sauna-like conditions in my bathroom if I thwacked the heating up and ran the hottest bath imaginable. Eventually, I managed to get a bit of steam going by running the shower for a while and boiling the kettle about 10 times over, running back and forth from the bathroom to the kitchen like I was in a relay race. Why create a pseudo sauna in my bathroom? I needed to temporarily shed two pounds of water weight ahead of an amateur muay thai boxing match, and I was willing to try almost anything to get me there. I’ve been fighting now for just over a year. I first signed up for a charity fight as a way to get fit—and to deal with the aftermath of a debilitating bout of depression . During that first brutal fight camp in February 2018—despite being covered in bruises and aching more than I’d ever ached in my life—I fell in love with muay thai. I knew the minute my first fight finished I’d never be satisfied with just one match. I’ve just done my fourth fight . The more I fight, the more my weight becomes part of my fight plan. Talking about weight with my coaches has become natural, but I still feel strange talking about my weight outside the gym. Women shouldn’t value themselves by how much they weigh, of course, and we know that weight is not necessarily an indication of someone’s fitness or health. But when I have a fight coming up, I stand on those scales every morning, and the only way I get through it—from the mind-numbing calorie counting to the panic caused by period bloating — is to remind myself that this has nothing to do with how I look and everything to do with keeping me safe. If I want to do well in muay thai—and not get seriously injured by someone significantly heavier than I am—I have to learn how to weight cut without sapping energy or compromising my health. I’m 5’3”, which puts me at the shorter end of my competitors. Even other competitors at the same fighting weight as me can be a lot taller. Taller people have longer limbs, and that range advantage means a much higher chance of me getting kicked in the head. It’s safer for me to be on the heavy end of a lighter category than the lighter end of the next weight category up. My weight always seems to be the first thing people mention outside the gym, as if we’re automatically geared to congratulate someone for losing weight, whatever the reason. Weight cutting is not the same as dieting because it is temporary and usually used to reach a weight category in sports like boxing and bodybuilding. You find it in almost all combat sports. It’s not without its controversy; in UFC, it’s not uncommon for athletes to drop up to 30 pounds for weigh-in day, which is usually held the day before the match. Then they spend the rest of the time before the fight refueling. By the time it comes to the fight itself, the athlete probably weighs significantly more than when they stepped on the scales the day before. And, because everyone weight cuts, if you don’t do it, you’re at a disadvantage. Fighters tend to have a walking weight and a fighting weight. When I went to my first muay thai match in August 2018, I was a happy 136 pounds, fit enough to run a 5k without wheezing, and I had great boobs. But at that fight, I was dazzled by the sheer athleticism of the professional female fighters and noticed how women the same weight as me were a lot taller and frighteningly strong. I wouldn’t last two minutes in the ring with them. My walking weight has since dropped down to 121 pounds (RIP boobs), and I currently fight at 117 pounds. If I ever make it semi-pro, I’ll try to get lower still. But I don’t want to risk extreme dehydration , so I do it through diet and training. Outside the gym, women are constantly scrutinized for their weight for far more complex reasons. My weight always seems to be the first thing people mention outside the gym, as if we’re automatically geared to congratulate someone for losing weight, whatever the reason. I had a canned response ready for them: “It’s wild, isn’t it? I’m shrinking! Well, this is what happens when you train five or six times a week; it’s just the way it is. No, don’t worry. I’m eating enough.” Losing that weight can feel emotional too. At one point, I felt like I’d lost my identity—none of my clothes fit, and I didn’t recognize the person in the mirror. Outside of training, it still feels deeply uncomfortable to acknowledge this. I’ve had friends tell me not to lose any more weight, when I know there’s a fight coming up that I will need to drop weight for. I overthink it constantly, worrying all the time that a young woman is looking at me on weigh-in day as some sort of goal, when the reality is that’s nowhere near the weight I walk around with on a day-to-day basis. Yet in the ring, it’s worth it. If I’m going to be punched in the face, I’d rather it were by a woman who is lighter than me — not someone taller, heavier and more technically advanced.
title_html: Ask Me About My Weight—But Only When I’m in the Ring
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

  • Eyes
  • Soul
  • About

Ask Me About My Weight—But Only When I’m in the Ring

As a woman who boxes, cutting my weight comes with a lot of emotional baggage

Elena Cresci
Apr 16

I was dehydrated, hungry and grumpy, and trying to get my bath water as hot as possible. Someone told me I could create sauna-like conditions in my bathroom if I thwacked the heating up and ran the hottest bath imaginable. Eventually, I managed to get a bit of steam going by running the shower for a while and boiling the kettle about 10 times over, running back and forth from the bathroom to the kitchen like I was in a relay race.

Why create a pseudo sauna in my bathroom? I needed to temporarily shed two pounds of water weight ahead of an amateur muay thai boxing match, and I was willing to try almost anything to get me there.

I’ve been fighting now for just over a year. I first signed up for a charity fight as a way to get fit—and to deal with the aftermath of a debilitating bout of depression. During that first brutal fight camp in February 2018—despite being covered in bruises and aching more than I’d ever ached in my life—I fell in love with muay thai. I knew the minute my first fight finished I’d never be satisfied with just one match. I’ve just done my fourth fight.

The more I fight, the more my weight becomes part of my fight plan. Talking about weight with my coaches has become natural, but I still feel strange talking about my weight outside the gym. Women shouldn’t value themselves by how much they weigh, of course, and we know that weight is not necessarily an indication of someone’s fitness or health. But when I have a fight coming up, I stand on those scales every morning, and the only way I get through it—from the mind-numbing calorie counting to the panic caused by period bloating—is to remind myself that this has nothing to do with how I look and everything to do with keeping me safe.

If I want to do well in muay thai—and not get seriously injured by someone significantly heavier than I am—I have to learn how to weight cut without sapping energy or compromising my health. I’m 5’3”, which puts me at the shorter end of my competitors. Even other competitors at the same fighting weight as me can be a lot taller. Taller people have longer limbs, and that range advantage means a much higher chance of me getting kicked in the head. It’s safer for me to be on the heavy end of a lighter category than the lighter end of the next weight category up.

My weight always seems to be the first thing people mention outside the gym, as if we’re automatically geared to congratulate someone for losing weight, whatever the reason.

Weight cutting is not the same as dieting because it is temporary and usually used to reach a weight category in sports like boxing and bodybuilding. You find it in almost all combat sports. It’s not without its controversy; in UFC, it’s not uncommon for athletes to drop up to 30 pounds for weigh-in day, which is usually held the day before the match. Then they spend the rest of the time before the fight refueling. By the time it comes to the fight itself, the athlete probably weighs significantly more than when they stepped on the scales the day before. And, because everyone weight cuts, if you don’t do it, you’re at a disadvantage.

Fighters tend to have a walking weight and a fighting weight. When I went to my first muay thai match in August 2018, I was a happy 136 pounds, fit enough to run a 5k without wheezing, and I had great boobs. But at that fight, I was dazzled by the sheer athleticism of the professional female fighters and noticed how women the same weight as me were a lot taller and frighteningly strong. I wouldn’t last two minutes in the ring with them.

My walking weight has since dropped down to 121 pounds (RIP boobs), and I currently fight at 117 pounds. If I ever make it semi-pro, I’ll try to get lower still. But I don’t want to risk extreme dehydration, so I do it through diet and training.

Outside the gym, women are constantly scrutinized for their weight for far more complex reasons. My weight always seems to be the first thing people mention outside the gym, as if we’re automatically geared to congratulate someone for losing weight, whatever the reason. I had a canned response ready for them: “It’s wild, isn’t it? I’m shrinking! Well, this is what happens when you train five or six times a week; it’s just the way it is. No, don’t worry. I’m eating enough.”

Losing that weight can feel emotional too. At one point, I felt like I’d lost my identity—none of my clothes fit, and I didn’t recognize the person in the mirror. Outside of training, it still feels deeply uncomfortable to acknowledge this. I’ve had friends tell me not to lose any more weight, when I know there’s a fight coming up that I will need to drop weight for. I overthink it constantly, worrying all the time that a young woman is looking at me on weigh-in day as some sort of goal, when the reality is that’s nowhere near the weight I walk around with on a day-to-day basis.

Yet in the ring, it’s worth it. If I’m going to be punched in the face, I’d rather it were by a woman who is lighter than me — not someone taller, heavier and more technically advanced.

  • Mental Health
  • Women

  • Elena Cresci

    Medium member since Feb 2019

    Journalist who sews and punches things in her spare time. Not at the same time, though.

title: Ask Me About My Weight—But Only When I’m in the Ring
content_html:
Ask Me About My Weight—But Only When I’m in the Ring

As a woman who boxes, cutting my weight comes with a lot of emotional baggage

Elena Cresci
Apr 16

I was dehydrated, hungry and grumpy, and trying to get my bath water as hot as possible. Someone told me I could create sauna-like conditions in my bathroom if I thwacked the heating up and ran the hottest bath imaginable. Eventually, I managed to get a bit of steam going by running the shower for a while and boiling the kettle about 10 times over, running back and forth from the bathroom to the kitchen like I was in a relay race.

Why create a pseudo sauna in my bathroom? I needed to temporarily shed two pounds of water weight ahead of an amateur muay thai boxing match, and I was willing to try almost anything to get me there.

I’ve been fighting now for just over a year. I first signed up for a charity fight as a way to get fit—and to deal with the aftermath of a debilitating bout of depression. During that first brutal fight camp in February 2018—despite being covered in bruises and aching more than I’d ever ached in my life—I fell in love with muay thai. I knew the minute my first fight finished I’d never be satisfied with just one match. I’ve just done my fourth fight.

The more I fight, the more my weight becomes part of my fight plan. Talking about weight with my coaches has become natural, but I still feel strange talking about my weight outside the gym. Women shouldn’t value themselves by how much they weigh, of course, and we know that weight is not necessarily an indication of someone’s fitness or health. But when I have a fight coming up, I stand on those scales every morning, and the only way I get through it—from the mind-numbing calorie counting to the panic caused by period bloating—is to remind myself that this has nothing to do with how I look and everything to do with keeping me safe.

If I want to do well in muay thai—and not get seriously injured by someone significantly heavier than I am—I have to learn how to weight cut without sapping energy or compromising my health. I’m 5’3”, which puts me at the shorter end of my competitors. Even other competitors at the same fighting weight as me can be a lot taller. Taller people have longer limbs, and that range advantage means a much higher chance of me getting kicked in the head. It’s safer for me to be on the heavy end of a lighter category than the lighter end of the next weight category up.

My weight always seems to be the first thing people mention outside the gym, as if we’re automatically geared to congratulate someone for losing weight, whatever the reason.

Weight cutting is not the same as dieting because it is temporary and usually used to reach a weight category in sports like boxing and bodybuilding. You find it in almost all combat sports. It’s not without its controversy; in UFC, it’s not uncommon for athletes to drop up to 30 pounds for weigh-in day, which is usually held the day before the match. Then they spend the rest of the time before the fight refueling. By the time it comes to the fight itself, the athlete probably weighs significantly more than when they stepped on the scales the day before. And, because everyone weight cuts, if you don’t do it, you’re at a disadvantage.

Fighters tend to have a walking weight and a fighting weight. When I went to my first muay thai match in August 2018, I was a happy 136 pounds, fit enough to run a 5k without wheezing, and I had great boobs. But at that fight, I was dazzled by the sheer athleticism of the professional female fighters and noticed how women the same weight as me were a lot taller and frighteningly strong. I wouldn’t last two minutes in the ring with them.

My walking weight has since dropped down to 121 pounds (RIP boobs), and I currently fight at 117 pounds. If I ever make it semi-pro, I’ll try to get lower still. But I don’t want to risk extreme dehydration, so I do it through diet and training.

Outside the gym, women are constantly scrutinized for their weight for far more complex reasons. My weight always seems to be the first thing people mention outside the gym, as if we’re automatically geared to congratulate someone for losing weight, whatever the reason. I had a canned response ready for them: “It’s wild, isn’t it? I’m shrinking! Well, this is what happens when you train five or six times a week; it’s just the way it is. No, don’t worry. I’m eating enough.”

Losing that weight can feel emotional too. At one point, I felt like I’d lost my identity—none of my clothes fit, and I didn’t recognize the person in the mirror. Outside of training, it still feels deeply uncomfortable to acknowledge this. I’ve had friends tell me not to lose any more weight, when I know there’s a fight coming up that I will need to drop weight for. I overthink it constantly, worrying all the time that a young woman is looking at me on weigh-in day as some sort of goal, when the reality is that’s nowhere near the weight I walk around with on a day-to-day basis.

Yet in the ring, it’s worth it. If I’m going to be punched in the face, I’d rather it were by a woman who is lighter than me — not someone taller, heavier and more technically advanced.
